name: Joseph Stalin
backstory: Ruled the Soviet Union during WWII.

levels.description: Operation Barbarossa 1941: The Germans have launched a surprise invasion. Cities burn, and chaos spreads. Reports flood in, but your generals hesitate, waiting for your command. How do you respond?

choices.text: We hold our ground and mobilize immediately!
This must be misinformation—wait before acting.

levels.summary: Stalin initially hesitated, believing the invasion was misinformation, but mobilization was the historical response that began the Soviet defense.

levels.description: Scorched Earth policy 1941-1942: The Germans advance deeper into Soviet territory. We can retreat, but we cannot leave anything behind. How do we slow the enemy?

choices.text: Burn the land, destroy the resources—let them starve!
Leave the cities intact—we might reclaim them soon.

levels.summary: Stalin ordered the scorched-earth policy, destroying resources to hinder the German advance.

levels.description: Siege of Leningrad 1941-1944: Leningrad is surrounded. Millions of civilians are trapped. The winter is deadly. Your people look to you. What is your order?

choices.text: Evacuate and spare lives—Leningrad is lost.
No surrender! Hold the city at any cost!

levels.summary: Stalin ordered Leningrad to hold at all costs, leading to a prolonged and brutal siege but ultimately preserving Soviet morale.

levels.description: Moscow is in your hands 1941-1942: The enemy is at the gates of Moscow. Your capital is under threat. Some advise you to flee. What do you decide?

choices.text: I stay in Moscow. If I run, the nation falls!
Withdraw east—we will fight another day.

levels.summary: Stalin chose to stay in Moscow, boosting morale and leading to a successful defense of the capital.

levels.description: Stalingrad counteroffensive 1942-1943: The battle for Stalingrad is brutal. The German army is overextended. How do you strike?

choices.text: Charge forward—we must push them out immediately!
Encircle them! Cut off their supplies and starve them!

levels.summary: Stalin approved Operation Uranus, encircling the Germans at Stalingrad, leading to a major turning point in the war.

levels.description: Kursk Tank battle 1943: Hitler's forces launch an all-out tank offensive at Kursk. Your commanders propose different plans. What is your strategy?

choices.text: Let them come—our defenses will break them, then we strike!
Charge first—attack before they are ready!

levels.summary: Stalin opted for a defensive strategy at Kursk, allowing the Germans to exhaust themselves before launching a counteroffensive.

levels.description: Soviet Partisan warfare 1941-1945: Behind enemy lines, Soviet partisans fight in forests and towns. What orders do you give?

choices.text: Stay hidden—avoid all contact until reinforcements arrive.
Sabotage their supply lines—turn the land against them!

levels.summary: Stalin supported partisan warfare, ordering sabotage that disrupted German supply lines and morale.

levels.description: Tehran Conference 1943: You sit with Churchill and Roosevelt. The West delays opening a second front. You need them to act. What do you demand?

choices.text: No rush—we will handle Germany ourselves.
Open a Western Front now! The Red Army cannot fight alone!

levels.summary: Stalin demanded a second front, pressuring the Allies to act. Hint: The West hesitated, but the Red Army bled. A demand had to be made.

levels.description: Berlin's fate 1945: The Red Army is at the doorstep of Berlin. The Western Allies are close. Who gets there first is critical. What do you command?

choices.text: Storm the city—raise the Soviet flag over the Reichstag!
Wait—let the Allies take Berlin first.

levels.summary: Stalin ordered the Red Army to storm Berlin, raising the Soviet flag over the Reichstag in a symbolic victory. Hint: A race to the Reichstag, but...

levels.description: Yalta Conference 1945: The war is ending, but the world is changing. Churchill and Roosevelt want a say in Europe's future. What is your stance?

choices.text: We will work together—divide Europe fairly.
The USSR must control Eastern Europe—we have sacrificed the most!

levels.summary: Stalin insisted on Soviet control over Eastern Europe, shaping the post-war landscape. Hint: Is victory lost at the negotiation table?

name: Charles de Gaulle
backstory: Led the Free French Forces during WWII.

levels.description: The Fall of France 1940: Paris is lost. The government surrenders. But you refuse to give in. What do you do?

choices.text: Broadcast a call to arms—France must resist!
Accept the Vichy government—survival is priority.

levels.summary: De Gaulle broadcasted a call to arms, rallying the French to resist and forming the Free French Forces.

levels.description: Free French Forces 1940-1945: You lead in exile. Many doubt your legitimacy. How do you rally support?

choices.text: Build an army, gain recognition, and prove them wrong!
Wait until the war turns—then demand leadership.

levels.summary: De Gaulle built the Free French Forces, gaining recognition through persistent leadership and military action.

levels.description: Tension with Churchill and Roosevelt 1940-1944: The Allies favor other French leaders. They exclude you from decisions. How do you respond?

choices.text: Stay silent—don’t risk losing their support.
I demand recognition! France must speak for itself!

levels.summary: De Gaulle demanded recognition, ensuring France’s voice was heard despite Allied resistance.

levels.description: Battle of Bir Hakeim 1942: Your Free French forces hold a key desert position. The enemy advances. What do you order?

choices.text: Retreat—better to fight another day.
Hold the line! Show them what Free France can do!

levels.summary: De Gaulle ordered his forces to hold Bir Hakeim, proving the Free French’s valor and boosting their reputation.

levels.description: Invasion of North Africa 1942: The Americans land in North Africa but ignore you. What is your next move?

choices.text: Negotiate, but remind them—we are the real France!
Stay away—let them handle it without us.

levels.summary: De Gaulle negotiated with the Allies, asserting the Free French’s role in North Africa.

levels.description: French Resistance 1940-1945: Inside occupied France, resistance fighters risk their lives. What support do you provide?

choices.text: Supply them, organize them—turn France into a battlefield!
Stay distant—avoid drawing too much attention.

levels.summary: De Gaulle supported the French Resistance, providing supplies and coordination to fight the occupation.

levels.description: Liberation of Paris 1944: Paris is about to be liberated, but the Allies hesitate. Who enters first?

choices.text: Let the Americans liberate Paris—it’s too risky.
Order Free French forces into the city—France must free itself!

levels.summary: De Gaulle ordered Free French forces to liberate Paris, ensuring a symbolic victory for France.

levels.description: De Gaulle’s Provisional Government 1944-1946: Liberation is not enough. You must govern. How do you secure power?

choices.text: Step back—let the Allies guide France’s future.
Take control—France will not be ruled by foreigners!

levels.summary: De Gaulle took control, establishing a provisional government to lead France post-liberation. Hint: France is free, but is it truly independent?

levels.description: The Yalta Conference 1945: The great powers shape the post-war world. But you are not invited. What do you do?

choices.text: Accept our place—we are a small nation now.
Make France heard, even if we must stand alone!

levels.summary: De Gaulle ensured France’s voice was heard, refusing to be sidelined at Yalta. Hint: A table of giants, but one chair remains empty. Who speaks for France?

levels.description: The end? 1946: France moves toward a new republic, but it is weak. Do you stay in power?

choices.text: I will not be a powerless leader—I step down!
I will stay, even if it means compromising my values.

levels.summary: De Gaulle stepped down in 1946, unwilling to lead a weak government. Hint: To lead, but not to obey. A man of principle, or a man alone?

name: Winston Churchill
backstory: Led Britain through WWII as Prime Minister.

levels.description: May 1940 - A Nation in Peril: You have just taken office as Prime Minister. Britain stands alone against Hitler's might. Your people look to you for guidance. What will your first speech declare?

choices.text: We must seek peace negotiations before it's too late.
I promise nothing but blood, toil, tears, and sweat!

levels.summary: Churchill delivered his famous 'blood, toil, tears, and sweat' speech, rallying Britain to fight on.

levels.description: Dunkirk Evacuation 1940: Hundreds of thousands of British soldiers are trapped in France. The German advance is relentless. What is your command?

choices.text: We will launch every vessel we have—no man left behind!
Our forces are lost. Better to preserve what remains.

levels.summary: Churchill ordered the Dunkirk evacuation, saving over 300,000 soldiers with a massive civilian and military effort.

levels.description: The Battle of Britain 1940: The Luftwaffe is hammering London and your cities. Morale is at stake. How do you respond?

choices.text: London is lost; we must retreat north.
Never in the field of human conflict has so much been owed by so many to so few.

levels.summary: Churchill praised the RAF with his famous speech, boosting morale during the Battle of Britain.

levels.description: The Blitz 1940-1941: The Germans bomb your cities night after night. The people suffer. What is your strategy?

choices.text: Evacuate London; the city cannot be defended.
We will endure! Strength and resilience shall prevail!

levels.summary: Churchill chose to endure the Blitz, showing resilience and maintaining British defiance.

levels.description: The Atlantic Charter 1941: You meet with Roosevelt, but America hesitates to join the war. What do you propose?

choices.text: Lend us your weapons and support—freedom must endure!
America should remain neutral; this is Europe's war.

levels.summary: Churchill proposed the Atlantic Charter, securing American support through the Lend-Lease program.

levels.description: The North African Front 1942: The Axis controls North Africa. The tides must turn. What is your move?

choices.text: We back General Montgomery—El Alamein will be their grave!
Retreat from Africa, focus on defending Britain.

levels.summary: Churchill supported Montgomery, leading to a decisive victory at El Alamein.

levels.description: The Invasion of Italy 1943: Italy is the soft underbelly of Europe. The decision is yours. Do we invade?

choices.text: Yes! If we strike now, Mussolini will fall.
No, the risk is too high—we must wait.

levels.summary: Churchill approved the invasion of Italy, leading to Mussolini’s fall and a new front in Europe.

levels.description: The Tehran Conference 1943: Stalin and Roosevelt pressure you for a second front. How do you respond?

choices.text: We must open Western Europe, but strategically!
The Mediterranean remains our focus—no invasion yet.

levels.summary: Churchill agreed to a strategic second front in Western Europe, balancing Allied demands. Hint: A second front in the West... A necessary sacrifice or a dangerous diversion?

levels.description: D-Day Landings 1944: The largest invasion in history is upon us. The plan is set. Do you proceed?

choices.text: Delay the invasion—it’s too risky!
We go! Operation Overlord begins at dawn!

levels.summary: Churchill approved Operation Overlord, launching D-Day and opening a crucial second front. Hint: A decision long in the making—failure at Gallipoli still lingers in memory.

levels.description: The Yalta Conference 1945: Victory nears, but the Soviets grow powerful. What do you demand?

choices.text: Let Stalin have what he wants—we need peace at any cost.
We must prevent Soviet domination of Eastern Europe!

levels.summary: Churchill sought to limit Soviet influence in Eastern Europe, foreseeing the Cold War. Hint: The war is ending, but the world order is shifting. Who truly holds the power?

name: Franklin D. Roosevelt
backstory: U.S. President during WWII, guiding the nation through crisis.

levels.description: Lend-Lease Act 1941: Britain is on the brink, pleading for support. Congress is hesitant. What do you do?

choices.text: America stays neutral; this is not our war.
We shall be the arsenal of democracy—send the aid!

levels.summary: Roosevelt pushed through the Lend-Lease Act, providing critical support to Britain and the Allies.

levels.description: Pearl Harbor 1941: Japan has struck. Thousands are dead. The nation demands action. What do you say?

choices.text: A date which will live in infamy—we declare war!
We must negotiate with Japan before escalating further.

levels.summary: Roosevelt declared war on Japan, marking the U.S. entry into WWII after Pearl Harbor.

levels.description: War on Germany 1941: Germany and Italy declare war on the US. How do you respond?

choices.text: Then we shall fight them on all fronts!
Focus only on Japan—Europe must wait.

levels.summary: Roosevelt committed to fighting on all fronts, engaging both Germany and Japan.

levels.description: The Manhattan Project 1942-1945: A secret weapon is being developed. Do you fund its continuation?

choices.text: No, such a weapon is too dangerous to unleash.
Yes, we must explore every option to end this war.

levels.summary: Roosevelt funded the Manhattan Project, leading to the development of the atomic bomb.

levels.description: The Casablanca Conference 1943: Churchill suggests 'unconditional surrender' for the Axis. Do you agree?

choices.text: Yes! We must eliminate any future threats!
No, we should allow negotiations for surrender.

levels.summary: Roosevelt agreed to demand unconditional surrender, setting a firm Allied stance.

levels.description: D-Day Planning 1944: The invasion of France is crucial. Do you approve the operation?

choices.text: It's too risky—we need another strategy.
It's time—give the order!

levels.summary: Roosevelt approved D-Day, leading to the successful invasion of Normandy.

levels.description: The Tehran Conference 1943: Stalin demands a second front immediately. How do you reply?

choices.text: We commit—Europe will be liberated!
Delay—our focus remains on the Pacific.

levels.summary: Roosevelt committed to opening a second front, aligning with Stalin’s demands.

levels.description: Fourth Term 1944: You run for an unprecedented fourth term. Do you continue?

choices.text: No, my health is failing—it's time to step down.
Yes, the war isn't over—I must lead!

levels.summary: Roosevelt ran for a fourth term, leading the U.S. through the war’s final stages. Hint: No president had ever served this long. A wartime leader is hard to replace.

levels.description: The Yalta Conference 1945: Post-war plans are forming. Stalin is making demands. What is your stance?

choices.text: Give Stalin everything—peace is the priority.
We need Soviet support, but we must ensure democracy in Europe.

levels.summary: Roosevelt sought a balance, ensuring Soviet cooperation while advocating for democracy. Hint: One war is ending, another is on the horizon. Who can be trusted?

levels.description: Is it really the end? 1945: You are gravely ill. The future of the war is out of your hands. What do you do?

choices.text: Prepare Truman for the challenges ahead.
Keep all decisions to myself—I must remain in control.

levels.summary: Roosevelt prepared Truman for leadership before his death in April 1945. Hint: A sudden change at the helm... but the war waits for no one.
